segments.text: AWS solutions architect associates
certification prep question 24 of 65. So
a company's compliance team requires
full control over all encryption keys
used to protect data in AWS. So they
must be able to create, disable and
schedule deletion of keys. Now all key
usage must be auditable through AWS
cloud trail. Company policy mandates
that encryption keys remain stored
within AWS infrastructure not on
premise. So which key management
solution meets these requirements? First
let's identify the key hints. One, full
control. Create, manage, and configure
policies. Two, disable and delete. So,
life cycle policy management is needed.
Number three, audit key usage. So, we
need some kind of awareness with cloud
trail or even active cloud trail
integration. Number four, stored in AWS.
So, not on premise and not external. So,
let's look at the options. Option one,
use AWS managed keys that AWS creates
and manages for each service. Option
two, use AWS owned keys that AWS uses
across multiple user accounts. Option
three, create customer managed keys in
AWS key management service with key
policies and cloud logging enabled.
Option four, deploy AWS cloud HSM and
manage keys and dedicated hardware
security modules. Option five, use S3
managed keys, the SSSE, basically
serverside encryption S3 for serverside
encryption. Drop your answer in the
comments below. So the hint says full
control plus stored in AWS. So AWS
control keys and on-remise options are
out. Option one, AWS manage keys are
convenient, but you can't disable or
delete them. Pretty much AWS controls
that life cycle. So that violates one of
the requirements. Option two, AWS own
keys are completely invisible to you. So
there's no audit trail, no control. You
don't even see them. Option four, cloud
HSM gives full control, but keys are in
dedicated hardware that you manage. So
that might be overkill and a higher
overhead than you actually need for the
requirements. Remember, we're just
trying to meet the requirements
minimally. No one said that we need FIPS
140 encryption, right? Or standards.
Option five, SSE S3 keys are managed
entirely by S3. So there's no real
customer control if you decide to use
SSE S3 keys versus using a KMS S3 key.
There's no control over the key life
cycle. So the correct answer is actually
option three, customer manage keys. So
you can create and control them
completely, disable, schedule deletion,
full life cycle management. Cloud trail
is going to log every use. So API calls
like encrypt, decrypt are all recorded
and they're stored. This is also stored
in KMS. So this is AWS infrastructure.
So this actually works for from a
validation perspective. Takeaway there's
three KMSs key types. There's AWS owned
which is invisible. There's AWS managed
which is visible but AWS controlled and
then there's customer manage where you
have full control. So when you need to
disable, delete or audit or just have
full control, CMK's customer managed
keys are really the only choice.

fullText: AWS solutions architect associates certification prep question 24 of 65. So a company's compliance team requires full control over all encryption keys used to protect data in AWS. So they must be able to create, disable and schedule deletion of keys. Now all key usage must be auditable through AWS cloud trail. Company policy mandates that encryption keys remain stored within AWS infrastructure not on premise. So which key management solution meets these requirements? First let's identify the key hints. One, full control. Create, manage, and configure policies. Two, disable and delete. So, life cycle policy management is needed. Number three, audit key usage. So, we need some kind of awareness with cloud trail or even active cloud trail integration. Number four, stored in AWS. So, not on premise and not external. So, let's look at the options. Option one, use AWS managed keys that AWS creates and manages for each service. Option two, use AWS owned keys that AWS uses across multiple user accounts. Option three, create customer managed keys in AWS key management service with key policies and cloud logging enabled. Option four, deploy AWS cloud HSM and manage keys and dedicated hardware security modules. Option five, use S3 managed keys, the SSSE, basically serverside encryption S3 for serverside encryption. Drop your answer in the comments below. So the hint says full control plus stored in AWS. So AWS control keys and on-remise options are out. Option one, AWS manage keys are convenient, but you can't disable or delete them. Pretty much AWS controls that life cycle. So that violates one of the requirements. Option two, AWS own keys are completely invisible to you. So there's no audit trail, no control. You don't even see them. Option four, cloud HSM gives full control, but keys are in dedicated hardware that you manage. So that might be overkill and a higher overhead than you actually need for the requirements. Remember, we're just trying to meet the requirements minimally. No one said that we need FIPS 140 encryption, right? Or standards. Option five, SSE S3 keys are managed entirely by S3. So there's no real customer control if you decide to use SSE S3 keys versus using a KMS S3 key. There's no control over the key life cycle. So the correct answer is actually option three, customer manage keys. So you can create and control them completely, disable, schedule deletion, full life cycle management. Cloud trail is going to log every use. So API calls like encrypt, decrypt are all recorded and they're stored. This is also stored in KMS. So this is AWS infrastructure. So this actually works for from a validation perspective. Takeaway there's three KMSs key types. There's AWS owned which is invisible. There's AWS managed which is visible but AWS controlled and then there's customer manage where you have full control. So when you need to disable, delete or audit or just have full control, CMK's customer managed keys are really the only choice.
